Hi Sebastian,

I think I understand.  For each intersection on the game boa=
rd I want ES-HyperNEAT to be able to discover a hidden node that is associa=
ted with only that intersection.  I also want it to be able to discover oth=
er nodes with multiple intersection associations. So, I need to choose a qu=
adtree resolution that will allow that.  If I apply ES-HyperNEAT to the app=
roach in the scalable Go paper, which rescales the Go board to a distance o=
f 2/18 between intersections (cells) so that a 19x19 board will fit the CPP=
N input range from -1 to 1, then I'm thinking the quadtree resolution would=
 need to allow a node to be expressed that is less than 1/18 from a board i=
ntersection, say 1/36.
This would potentially allow 3277 nodes in the hidde=
n layer for a 19x19 board, but hopefully pruning from the evolution of lowe=
r board sizes will keep the number significantly lower.  If not, I need a m=
ore powerful computer.

Tony

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Sebastian Risi <=
sebastian.risi@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Tony,
> 
> Since you still define the pos=
ition of the input nodes and ES-HyperNEAT
> starts to discover the hidden n=
odes from there, you can still have input
> nodes at the borders. The one t=
hing that's a little trickier is getting
> hidden nodes directly at the bou=
ndaries (e.g. x=3D-1), because the location
> of a new hidden node is deter=
mined by the center of quadtree square. The
> initial square used for the q=
uadtree extraction
> normally spans the space from (-1, -1) to (1, 1), so s=
imilarly to what you
> suggested you could have an initial square that e.g.=
 spans the space from
> (-1.2, -1.2)  to (1.2, 1.2). This way you could hav=
e hidden nodes expressed
> closer to e.g. x=3D-1. However, I'm not sure how=
 important it is to be able
> to express hidden nodes at exactly those loca=
tions and I believe it
> probably doesn't hurt the algorithm that the hidde=
n node might be expressed
> at a slightly different location (e.g. -0.9).
>=
 
> One thing that would be different from previously published ES-HyperNEA=
T
> experiments with a domain like Go is that you have a grid-like setup of=

> input nodes instead of having inputs in a horizontal line (e.g. at y=3D-=
1). A
> typical setup for HyperNEAT for these kind of domains uses multiple=

> different two-dimensional layers of neurons. An example can be found in
=
> this paper: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/gauci_ppsn10.pdf (figure 1)
> =

> For ES-HyperNEAT it would probably make sense to give the CPPN an
> addi=
tional input (instead of an additional output as in the HyperNEAT
> paper),=
 which would determine if you query connections from the input to
> the hid=
den layer or from the hidden layer to the output layer. This way the
> ES-H=
yperNEAT algorithm could just be applied to the one weight output
> pattern=
, as in the previously published experiments.
> 
> Please let me know if th=
is helps or if you have any other questions about
> ES-HyperNEAT. We will a=
lso release an updated version of ES-HyperNEAT
> implemented in C# soon.
> =

> Sebastian
> 
> On Wed, Apr 11, 2012 at 12:29 AM, wilsontg80 <wilsontg@..=
.> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> >
> > On second thought, if I'm evolving a 5x=
5 board evaluator and treat it as
> > if it is 7x7, then band pruning will =
remove the excess edge nodes without
> > automatically clobbering the 5x5 e=
dge nodes. I wonder how effective that
> > would be.
> >
> > Tony
> >
> >
>=
 > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wilsontg@> wrote:
> > >
> > >=

> > > What I mean is the band pruning seems too restrictive. Suppose a CPP=
N
> > substrate is being pruned for a Go game board evaluator. If ideally t=
he
> > weights along the board edge should be expressed they will be remove=
d by
> > band pruning. Am I missing something?
> > >
> > > Tony
> > >
> > >=
 --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > >
> > =
> >
> > > > Hi Tony, I believe the issue there is with the definition of a =
"band":
> > > >
> > > > "points that are enclosed by at least two neighbors=
 on opposite sides
> > (e.g. left and right) with di fferent CPPN activatio=
n levels"
> > > >
> > > > Note that the points in the outer black region do=
 not have _two_
> > neighbors of different level on opposite sides, so I be=
lieve that is the
> > reason they are pruned away. However, it's possible t=
hat I'm
> > misunderstanding the question, in which case please let me know=
.
> > > >
> > > > Regarding the quote that says, "the CPPN speaks a languag=
e through its
> > pattern," this idea conveys that of course there is more =
than one way to
> > interpret the patterns output by CPPNs for this purpose=
, and any such
> > method of interpretation is a kind of language. In other=
 words, there might
> > be other perfectly legitimate ways of deciding whic=
h connections to express
> > from an infinite-resolution pattern that are d=
ifferent from the method in
> > the paper (i.e. those would be different "l=
anguages" for the CPPN to
> > express what it wants).
> > > >
> > > > Howev=
er, the "language" suggested in the paper is nice in the sense
> > that it =
allows the CPPN to express one type of connection without being
> > forced =
to express another at the same time - that's what the band pruning
> > achi=
eves. Otherwise you'd get points chosen on both sides of a sharp
> > border=
, forcing connections often to be chosen in pairs (which seems an
> > undes=
irable tendency).
> > > >
> > > > ken
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > --- In neat@y=
ahoogroups.com, "wilsontg80" <wilsontg@> wrote:
> > > > >
> > > > > I am pu=
zzled by the result of band pruning in Figure 3: Example
> > point selectio=
n in two dimensions, from Evolving the Placement and Density
> > of Neurons=
 in the HyperNEAT Substrate. It seems like the information
> > inherent in =
the image should include points along the black-white edge of
> > the outer=
 black region, but band pruning removes them all. The figure
> > explains "=
In effect, the CPPN speaks a language through its pattern that
> > denotes =
exactly which weights within the hypercube should be expressed." I
> > am c=
urious why "language" is used here.
> > > > >
> > > > > My goal is to add i=
terated ES-HyperNEAT to the C++ version at
> > https://github.com/MisterTea=
/HyperNEAT. I am presently a hobbyist (my
> > profession is embedded softwa=
re engineering) but considering to someday
> > pursue a PhD involving Hyper=
NEAT, etc.
> > > > >
> > > > > Thanks,
> > > > > Tony Wilson
